IMPORTANT PLEASE READ if you plan to do this build.

If you do this, do not use the same bottle over and over. Change out the bottle often, or better yet get a bottle that can be washed and reused, because 2 liter soda bottles are supposed to be used ONCE and thrown away. Information below.

#1 - PET (Polyethylene Terephthalate) The numbers on the bottle's bottom has a purpose and a meaning. Your pet could get sick if you aren't careful.

PET is one of the most commonly used plastics in consumer products, and is found in most water and pop bottles, and some packaging. It is intended for SINGLE use applications; repeated use increases the risk of leaching and bacterial growth. PET plastic is difficult to decontaminate, and proper cleaning requires harmful chemicals. Polyethylene terephthalates may leach carcinogens.

Leaching is where plastic bottles release small amounts of chemicals over long periods of time. ... It increases over time because the plastic is leaching chemicals into the water.

Hey, people watching this: If you're clumsy as an ox with Parkinson's disease like I am, there's a trick to not spilling the water everywhere when you turn the bottle over: Once the bottle's full, wet the mouth of it and then stick some kind of stiff plastic on top of it, like a cut-out disc from a coffee can lid or a flattened piece of another soda bottle. Then, depress the center of the plastic into the mouth of the bottle just a little bit, like when you're putting the top on a tupperware container. The plastic should vacuum to the bottle and stick there, even when the bottle is turned over. From there you can position the bottle however you need to, and then when you're done you can just slide the plastic stopper off.
